sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Cough - Nasal congestion, Associated with the common cold: 5 mL (hydrocodone 5mg/pseudoephedrine 60 mg) ORALLY every 4 to 6 hours as needed; MAX 20 mL (4 doses) in 24 hours

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years of age

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatric: start at lower end of dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Cough - Nasal congestion, Associated with the common cold

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with MAOI therapy or within 14 days of discontinuation of MAOI; risk of increased blood pressure or hypertensive crisis
  • hypersensitivity to hydrocodone, pseudoephedrine, or any inactive constituents of the product
  • narrow angle glaucoma
  • hypertension, severe
  • coronary artery disease, severe
  • urinary retention

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• abdominal conditions, acute; diagnosis or clinical course may be obscured
  • Addison disease
  • asthma
  • cardiovascular collapse with hypotension has been reported (pseudoephedrine component)
  • cardiovascular disorders
  • CNS stimulation with convulsion has been reported (pseudoephedrine component)
  • concomitant use with alcohol, other opioids, antihistamines, antipsychotics, anxiolytics, or other CNS depressants should be avoided
  • concomitant use with tricyclic antidepressants not recommended; potential for increased effects of either the antidepressant or hydrocodone
  • diabetes mellitus
  • drug dependence, psychic, or physical and tolerance with repeated use, or abuse/misuse may occur
  • head injury, other intracranial lesions, or preexisting increased intracranial pressure; increased risk of cerebrospinal fluid pressure elevation and obscuring of clinical course; avoid use
  • hepatic impairment, severe
  • prostatic hypertrophy
  • renal impairment, severe; pseudoephedrine accumulation may occur
  • respiratory depression, dose-related (hydrocodone component), may occur
  • thyroid disease
  • urethral stricture
  • report suspected adverse events to Hawthorn Pharmaceuticals, Inc at 1-800-856-4393, or at www.hawthornrx.com, or to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088, or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia
  • Neurologic:Confusion, Dizziness, Insomnia, Lethargy, Sedated, Somnolence, Tremor
  • Psychiatric:Anxiety, Disturbance in mood, Dysphoric mood, Fear, Feeling nervous
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Abnormal cardiovascular function
  • Gastrointestinal:Paralytic ileus
  • Neurologic:Central nervous system stimulation, Raised intracranial pressure
  • Respiratory:Respiratory depression
  • Other:Drug dependence

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The combination oral solution hydrocodone bitartrate/pseudoephedrine hydrochloride is a semisynthetic centrally-acting opioid antitussive/sympathomimetic amine, respectively for the treatment of cough and nasal congestion associated with the common cold. The exact mechanism of action of hydrocodone is unknown; however, the antitussive effects are thought due to direct action on the cough center. The sympathomimetic effects of pseudoephedrine exert a decongestant action on the nasal mucosa

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Hydrocodone, Tmax, Oral: 1.4 hours
  • Pseudoephedrine, Tmax, Oral: 1.8 hours
  • Pseudoephedrine, effects of food: not affected

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hydrocodone, liver
  • Hydrocodone, metabolites: (active) hydromorphone, norcodeine, 6-beta-hydrocodol, 6-alpha-hydrocodol, 6-beta-hydromorphol, 6-alpha-hydromorphol
  • Pseudoephedrine, liver, 10% to 30%.
  • Pseudoephedrine, metabolites: norpseudoephedrine (active).

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Hydrocodone, Renal: 26%
  • Pseudoephedrine, Renal: 70% to 90%
  • Pseudoephedrine, Dialyzable: no
  • Pseudoephedrine, Total body clearance: 9.2 to 10.3 mL/min/kg (pediatric)

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause drowsiness or impairment of mental and physical performance.
  • Drug may cause sedation, mental clouding, lethargy, anxiety, fear, dysphoria, dizziness, physical or psychic dependence, mood changes, nervousness, or insomnia.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of respiratory depression.
  • Counsel patient with cardiovascular disease to immediately report arrhythmias, palpitations, or hypotension.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of CNS stimulation such as irritability, tremors, or convulsions.
  • Advise patient to measure solution with an accurate mL measuring device. Do not use a household teaspoon.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult a healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
  • Warn patient to avoid use of alcohol, antihistamines, antipsychotics, anxiolytics, other opioids, or other nonessential CNS depressants, including tricyclic antidepressants.
  • Instruct patient to avoid concomitant use with MAO inhibitors or within 14 days of discontinuing an MAOI.
